info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 10 at 2:24AM EST until January 10 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Saluda River above Old Easley Rd, 5 W Greenville affecting Greenville and Pickens Counties. .A potent storm system produced 3.5-4.5 inches of rainfall across the upper Saluda River watershed from from early Tuesday morning through Tuesday afternoon. This rainfall quickly overwhelmed saturated soils and resulted in excessive runoff and significant stream rises for all forks of the Saluda River and associated tributaries. This excessive flow has caused portions of the upper Saluda River to exceed bankfull or Action/Advisory Stage and crest near Minor Flood Stage, causing common, nuisance flooding of low-lying areas. The floodwave peak is passing the Saluda River near Old Easley Rd and the river crest is imminent around 9.9 feet. The river will begin a recession early Wednesday morning and fall below Action/Advisory Stage early Wednesday night. ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Saluda River above Old Easley Rd, 5 W Greenville. * WHEN...Until this evening. * IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Minor Flood Stage. Common, deeper flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to the Saluda River is developing with lesser impacts to vulnerable property. More significant floodwaters are beginning to impact low-lying areas downstream of Saluda Dam, including the lowest elevation of residential yards along Shop Ct, Covenant Dr, Riverview Dr, Riverview Cir, and Old Easley Bridge Rd. Floodwaters may be approaching River Rd near Myers Ln. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:45 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 9.8 feet and cresting. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 3.9 feet early Monday morning. - Action/Advisory Stage is 8.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 9.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued beforethis evening at 700 PM EST.
